8BB0F254CE3944EF812C7DD400AF09FB.description:
Definite integrals, including analytical approach. Areas of a region enclosed by a curve y = f(x) and
the x-axis, where f(x) can be positive or negative,
without the use of technology.
Areas between curves.

Indefinite integral of x
n
(n ∈ ℚ), sinx, cosx,
1
x
 and e
x
.

x
dx = ln x + C
The composites of any of these with the linear

2

Integration by inspection (reverse chain rule) or by

0EBBFF3055524FF197CE7C12761AE8DE.description:
Kinematic problems involving displacement s,
velocity v, acceleration a and total distance
travelled

7D5B0D3AAD9447FCBD952C1918BFF379.description:
Local maximum and minimum points.
Testing for maximum and minimum. Optimization.  Points of inflexion with zero and non-zero gradients.

864DB998E68B45BB9001BF0FF9B69581.description:
The second derivative.
Graphical behaviour of functions, including the
relationship between the graphs of f , f ′ and f ″.

36BB4E5756B7479AB5AAEB6E8D1D9348.description:
Derivative of x
n
(n ∈ ℚ), sinx, cosx, e
x
 and lnx.
Differentiation of a sum and a multiple of these
functions.
The chain rule for composite functions. The product and quotient rules.

DD12F8B3524F455985F4A6D32750FAD1.description:
Introduction to integration as anti-differentiation of
functions of the form f(x) = axn + bxn − 1 + ....,
where n ∈ ℤ, n ≠ − 1   Anti-differentiation with a boundary condition to
determine the constant term.  Definite integrals using technology.
Area of a region enclosed by a curve y = f(x)
and the x -axis, where f(x) > 0.

26ACF178D8064E4FB5A87724F2989D47.description:
Tangents and normals at a given point, and their
equations.

D179C47379054A4B96DD0916A35B9D44.description:
Derivative of f(x) = axn
 is f ′(x) = anxn − 1
, n ∈ ℤ
The derivative of functions of the form
f(x) = axn + bxn − 1
. . . .
where all exponents are integers.

A536E0174FCA47849D96E09B0608D9B2.description:
Increasing and decreasing functions.
Graphical interpretation of
f ′(x) > 0, f ′(x) = 0, f ′(x) < 0

4E97F93BCA0142C598A638F9878D145B.description:
Introduction to the concept of a limit. Derivative interpreted as gradient function and as
rate of change.

FBA22A021F4B41769B657F4591E543E8.description:
Standardization of normal variables (z- values). Inverse normal calculations where mean and
standard deviation are unknown

8370348B4F4948FCA8270D31733510A0.description:
Formal definition and use of the formulae:
P(A|B) = P(A ∩ B)
P(B)
 for conditional probabilities, and
P(A|B) = P(A) = P(A|B′) for independent events.

FEC9B4DD6ABC4758859E3506E7F071F3.description:
Equation of the regression line of x on y.
Use of the equation for prediction purposes.

20490CC9148540A9B484D060BA24A281.description:
The normal distribution and curve.
Properties of the normal distribution.
Diagrammatic representation. Normal probability calculations. Inverse normal calculations

78A6D1D490F245948B2CBC912E77B238.description:
Binomial distribution.
Mean and variance of the binomial distribution.

2F3B3882FDFA45608FD8EABA1B94F0EC.description:
Concept of discrete random variables and their
probability distributions.
Expected value (mean), for discrete data.
Applications.

8547AB084F1142FA9E52730DEE06A840.description:
Use of Venn diagrams, tree diagrams, sample space
diagrams and tables of outcomes to calculate
probabilities.
Combined events:
P(A ∪ B) = P(A) + P(B) − P(A ∩ B).
Mutually exclusive events: P(A ∩ B) = 0. Conditional probability: P(A|B) = P(A ∩ B)
P(B)
. Independent events: P(A ∩ B) = P(A)P(B).

8CDEB08E35FD4963B14389AE9FD9B98D.description:
Concepts of trial, outcome, equally likely outcomes,
relative frequency, sample space (U) and event.
The probability of an event A is P(A) = n(A)
n(U)
.
The complementary events A and A′
(not A). Expected number of occurrences

D541F7DB35E74D62A5F821230FEF7324.description:
Linear correlation of bivariate data.
Pearson’s product-moment correlation coefficient, r. Scatter diagrams; lines of best fit, by eye, passing
through the mean point. Use of the equation of the regression line for
prediction purposes.
Interpret the meaning of the parameters, a and b, in
a linear regression y = ax + b.

204D5A5A62164C5D91F18430D282CCB6.description:
Measures of central tendency (mean, median and
mode).
Estimation of mean from grouped data. Modal class. Measures of dispersion (interquartile range,
standard deviation and variance).
Effect of constant changes on the original data.Quartiles of discrete data.

A8C254BB902546DCA19159D4D921A6D4.description:
Presentation of data (discrete and continuous):
frequency distributions (tables). Histograms.
Cumulative frequency; cumulative frequency
graphs; use to find median, quartiles, percentiles,
range and interquartile range (IQR).Production and understanding of box and whisker
diagrams.

CBB1841F296A44A9A8078BCB67AE68EA.description:
Concepts of population, sample, random sample,
discrete and continuous data. Reliability of data sources and bias in sampling. Interpretation of outliers. Sampling techniques and their effectiveness.

9BF49B84D1344532B0924759C24BCCCB.description:
Solving trigonometric equations in a finite interval,
both graphically and analytically. Equations leading to quadratic equations in
sinx, cosx or tanx.

2500BE79CC4F445383B8B3E30019DC6D.description: The circular function, sinx, cosx, tanx, amplitude, their periodic nature, and their graphs, composite functions of the form f(x)=asin(b(x+c))+d, transformations, real-life contexts

13001D2F77154D0388DD3EDC1BA065A4.description: the pythagorean identity, double angle identities for sin and cosine, the relationship between trig ratios

541FDA8FBC294C35A0BC739FAFBD0F89.description: Definition of cos and sin in terms of the unit circle. Definition of tan as sin/cos. exact values of trig ratios of 0, pi/6, pi/4, pi/3, pi/2 and their multiples. extension of sine rule to the ambiguous case

CA92186A08624541892295FB75FDF680.description:
The circle: radian measure of angles; length of an
arc; area of a sector

6CEB2091DE1D4B7AB78F8A46D925DD44.description:
Applications of right and non-right angled
trigonometry, including Pythagoras’s theorem.
Angles of elevation and depression. Construction of labelled diagrams from written
statements

E0AC4310A1D141B3B76B52629ED9C05A.description:
Use of sine, cosine and tangent ratios to find the
sides and angles of right-angled triangles. The sine rule The cosine rule:  Area of a triangle

51815571471B460E8C16DAEEED80C2F1.description:
The distance between two points in threedimensional space, and their midpoint. Volume and surface area of three-dimensional solids
including right-pyramid, right cone, sphere,
hemisphere and combinations of these solids.
The size of an angle between two intersecting lines
or between a line and a plane.

ABD9F99929584601A68F49DC9036E560.description:
Transformations of graphs.
Translations: y = f(x) + b; y = f(x − a).
Reflections (in both axes): y = − f(x); y = f( − x).
Vertical stretch with scale factor p: y = p f(x).
Horizontal stretch with scale factor 1
q
: y = f(qx). Composite transformations.

E24832C99685449D9B32357842FAAFC4.description:
Solving equations, both graphically and analytically. Use of technology to solve a variety of equations,
including those where there is no appropriate
analytic approach. Applications of graphing skills and solving
equations that relate to real-life situations

2193D68B46E14E1D8657154D46EA36C2.description:
Exponential functions and their graphs:
f(x) = a
x
, a > 0, f(x) = ex
Logarithmic functions and their graphs:
f(x) = logax, x > 0, f(x) = lnx, x > 0.

58413F17B8C54E15A9D21A558CEAE7FC.description:
The reciprocal function f(x) = 1
x
, x ≠ 0: its graph
and self-inverse nature.
Rational functions of the form f(x) = ax + b
cx + d
 and
their graphs.
Equations of vertical and horizontal asymptotes.

2B644449BD0E40D7AE97BCF7DE760E76.description:
Solution of quadratic equations and inequalities.
The quadratic formula. The discriminant Δ = b
2 − 4ac and the nature of the
roots, that is, two distinct real roots, two equal real
roots, no real roots

9376F541E9104973B66AA64335412DF2.description:
The quadratic function f(x) = ax2 + bx + c: its
graph, y -intercept (0, c). Axis of symmetry.
The form f(x) = a(x − p)(x − q), x- intercepts (p, 0) and (q, 0).
The form f(x) = a (x − h)
2 + k, vertex (h, k).

034979509BA04F1BBA62266622C80EE3.description:
Composite functions. Identity function. Finding the inverse function
f −1(x).

30BD33E20C604B6B93424D7C7F0EF7EB.description:
Determine key features of graphs. Finding the point of intersection of two curves or
lines using technology

4C4CB9AB8C724C949CA341C16394601B.description:
The graph of a function; its equation y = f(x). Creating a sketch from information given or a
context, including transferring a graph from screen
to paper.
Using technology to graph functions including their
sums and differences.

17CB0A8B55194F2AB3E035F41DC2D1B4.description:
Concept of a function, domain, range and graph.
Function notation, for example f(x), v(t), C(n).
The concept of a function as a mathematical model. Informal concept that an inverse function reverses
or undoes the effect of a function.
Inverse function as a reflection in the line y = x, and
the notation f −1(x).

60EA793F678544F284448C1A881DA62F.description:
Different forms of the equation of a straight line.
Gradient; intercepts.
Lines with gradients m1 and m2
Parallel lines m1 = m2.
Perpendicular lines m1 × m2 = − 1

E8582CF33CB442EFA328386A5C827A0B.description: The binomial theorem; pascal's triangle, combination nCr

221BECCA3B5A4591BE2801CAA07EBF4E.description: Sum of infinite convergent geometric sequences.

830883C35EFF4E5EAB5C8035F7BA1B17.description:
Laws of exponents with rational exponents. Laws of logarithms.Change of base of a logarithm. Solving exponential equations, including using
logarithms.

B7E5677CC71A4310A0AC80161803BCF6.description:
Simple deductive proof, numerical and algebraic;
how to lay out a left-hand side to right-hand side
(LHS to RHS) proof.
The symbols and notation for equality and identity

DB17D682FB91427AB669E6408BAD301A.description:
Laws of exponents with integer exponents.Introduction to logarithms with base 10 and e.
Numerical evaluation of logarithms using
technology.

C1EC991CF8894386A8A9D7B75B9FB79A.description:
Financial applications of geometric sequences and
series:
• compound interest
• annual depreciation.

5AE4B3A6E85046DE8D95DFE984CEEF95.description:
Geometric sequences and series.
Use of the formulae for the n th term and the sum of
the first n terms of the sequence.Use of sigma notation for the sums of geometric
sequences. Applications

FA92D6F281454A1280A9B69A284E847E.description:
Arithmetic sequences and series.
Use of the formulae for the n
th term and the sum of
the first n terms of the sequence.
Use of sigma notation for sums of arithmetic
sequences. Applications. Analysis, interpretation and prediction where a
model is not perfectly arithmetic in real life

2AEBE4D0EDCF4AA9BFD56225C63F158B.description: Operations with numbers in the form of ax10^k where 1<=a<10 and k is an integer
